key_title: Key to the species of Amaranthus

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Amaranthaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Amaranthaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Amaranthaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Fruit circumsciss; bracts and bracteoles (except in A. graecizans) rigid and spinescent, subequal to or exceeding perianth
Fruit not or irregularly dehiscent; bracts and bracteoles (except in rare forms of A. albus) shorter than perianth, generally not spinescent
Flowers in small axillary clusters; tepals 2 or 3
Flowers in dense spikes or spike-like panicles, terminal and in upper axils; tepals 3–5
Bracts and bracteoles spinescent, c. twice as long as perianth
Bracteoles not spinescent, shorter than perianth
Inflorescence greenish (rarely reddish), spikes erect or spreading but not drooping
Inflorescence reddish, purplish or yellowish, usually with long drooping spikes 15 cm long or more
Tepals of female flowers acute, not mucronate
Tepals of female flowers obtuse, truncate or emarginate, usually shortly mucronate

Inflorescence somewhat lax, usually with many short branches arising at near right-angles from main axis, branches typically 5–8 mm diam. at midway; longest bracts 2–3.5 mm long; tepals 5, 1.5–2 mm long
Inflorescence stiff, relatively few-branched, branches typically 1 cm diam. or more at midway; longest bracts 4–6 mm long; tepals 3–5 (often within one inflorescence) 2.5–3 mm long
Utricle globoid to slightly compressed, distinctly longer than perianth
Utricle distinctly compressed, shorter than or equal to perianth
Tepals 2 or 3
Tepals 5 (rarely 4)
Bracts and bracteoles not spinescent
Bracts and bracteoles spinescent
Flowers in spikes or spike-like panicles (all terminal or sometimes also in upper axils); mature utricles brownish or green
Flowers in globular axillary clusters; mature utricles blackish
Prostrate perennial with ± hairy stems; seed much smaller than utricle; perianth segments mostly 2
Ascending to erect annual, almost glabrous; seed almost filling utricle; perianth segments mostly 3
Tepals c. 2 mm long in fruit; ± prostrate plants; inflorescence spicate or axillary
Tepals 4–7 mm long in fruit; erect plants with inflorescence of axillary clusters
Utricle c. twice as long as perianth; flowers in dense axillary clusters
Utricle slightly exceeding perianth; inflorescence spicate, terminal
